captions.text: Good Morning John.

I want to start this off by saying that I
am not a doctor, I'm not a counselor, I haven't

experienced sexual abuse, I'm just a person
with some thoughts that hopefully could be
helpful. To someone.

Sex is complicated, in like, every way imaginable.
This is not aided by the fact that we have

a general societal taboo against discussing
it. So when we do talk about it, it's often

shrouded in metaphors and innuendo and bombasticity.
That means a lot of the sexual norms of our

culture are mysterious, and we don't actually
talk about them; we just sort of infer them.

I think that's dumb. And that's part of why
I helped Nick and Lindsey start sexplanations.

I think that our culture has kind of a messed
up relationship with sex. We somehow have

made these relationships, uh, into, like,
predator/prey relationships. Like, one person

is the, you know, the cruise missile of desire,
and the other one is the sweet, chaste little

kitten. And the cruise missile has to get
the kitten and the kitten runs away. I don't
know why it's a cruise missile and a kitten.

I do know, though, that this is a dumb system.
I think that a lot of the joy and wonder and

excitement of a romantic relationship comes
from those moments of excitedly discovering

that both parties are into this. We're in-
we're both into this! That's a great feeling!

The attack missile/kitten relationship does
not encourage that.

I wanna be clear, I'm explaining culture but
I'm not excusing the behavior. When we're

set up to assume that the kitten is gonna
run whether the kitten wants the cruise missile

or not, that enables abuse. In my opinion
this is, I'm sure not all of the reason, but

one of of the big reasons why sexual abuse
is so common in our culture.

Okay, I said sexual abuse, but what- what
is sexual abuse? Legally, the definition has

to be very specific, so that it can stand
up in court. So it's different state to state,

country to country. But for the purposes of
having a general definition, let's just say

that sexual abuse is when one party is being
coerced into doing something sexual that they
do not want to do.

That can be because the victim is incapacitated,
or because the abuser is an authority figure,

or because the victim is placed in a dangerous
situation where they feel like they don't

have the option of saying no or getting out
of the situation. The gender of the parties
is irrelevant, it can be sex, it can be kissing.

If one person doesn't want to be doing what
they are doing and they are being coerced

or pressured into doing it, then that is abuse.
And it is ubiquitous. And it needs to not

be, because it holds us back as a culture.
We have to rid ourselves of that outdated

and rotten conception that sexual relationships
are like predator/prey things.

Let's zoom in for this. Romantic relationships
can be wonderful, but you have to have that

magical thing, consent. And not saying no
is not the same as saying yes. We need to

communicate, we need to be sensitive, we need
to talk about what we do and don't want to

do, and we have to respect and NOT pressure
people when they don't want to do something.

This video is part of a long conversation
that is going to continue to be had for a

long time. But John and I have some ideas
about how to keep it moving. First, we've

already started working with a group of nerdfighters,
including some survivors of sexual abuse,

who will be working as a task force against
abuse and assault.

Second, we want to produce and fund a series
of videos that discusses abuse and consent

and sexual relationships, especially in light
of the new digital world, like where does
Skype fit into it all, right?

And third, we're looking to partner with some
existing sexual assault organizations to bring

their work and their resources into our community,
and hopefully into other online communities

as well. John, I know we're not gonna fix
the whole world but I'm pleased to be in a

position where we can at least start to help
enable some positive change.
I'll see you on Tuesday.

If you're in an abusive relationship or you
think you might be and you're just not sure,

there are links in the description to help
you figure out where you're at, and to people

who you can call or go to for help. Sometimes
just figuring out the abusive nature of a

relationship can be a huge challenge, and
once you're in there, it can seem like it
is impossible to escape, but it is not.

comments.text:
+Blah b  What dictionary is that definition from? I was sure the common 
definition was simply "child lover".

So any child who has finished puberty is entitled to give their consent to 
an adult of any age? Are you aware some children don't experience puberty 
until their late teens while others (especially overweight young girls) 
begin as early as 7 or 8 (reminder; this is kindergarten age)? What about 
children as young as 3 or 4 years who were sexually molested and now behave 
hyper-sexually and instigate sexual contact with other adults? Just because 
an under-developed and inherently naive brain wants it does that mean it 
should be legal?

Of course it doesn't.

You think I would destroy lives in support of what I deem appropriate age 
of consent laws, however I could argue you think it's fine to destroy lives 
of children by advocating social acceptance of consensual statutory rape 
and assault. There are still victims because children do and want things 
they do not understand wholly as concepts nor their consequences good or 
bad, and that's what I'm concerned about. And why risk it? Why do you 
insist on siding with an adult's desire to date a child over the child's 
risk of being taken advantage of, especially when the adult need only wait 
a few years, which is nothing if both parties truly loved each other for 
the person they were. Although I cannot fathom why an adult would love a 
child personality enough to not wait until that child was more of a 
relatable and cognitively mature, I can assure you that's not why I'm 
defending my opinion so fervently, at least consciously.

I'm not conservative at all, by the way, I truly have disdain for 
victim-less crimes and pervasive crimes concerning sex and sexuality in the 
US (bestiality for one clearly shouldn't be illegal despite my distaste for 
such interests) but I cannot accept this as one, although I'm sure there 
are rare (keeping in mind that something rare would happen many times when 
we're talking about a group of 7 billion) exceptions where everyone is 
happy and the child isn't damaged.

And that's why I don't think calling me "entitled" is the most appropriate 
word. I'm going to lay it all completely out for you; I am, in fact, 
entitled in a progressive society to tell a person he cannot physically, 
verbally, or mentally abuse another person, I am entitled to support taking 
reasonable measures and precautions to avoid such situations from 
happening, the question is then, what percentage of these kind of 
relationships would "work out" and end without damaging the child? I must 
personally refute any claim that it is the majority based from my own 
knowledge in both criminal and adolescent neuropsychology, and that's why 
leaning on the safe side and choosing to protect the child from significant 
risk over the adult's desire and intolerance to wait until the child is 
older is so obviously more important, *especially* reflecting that the 
ruling isn't permanent and in most cases the adult would only have to wait 
a few years for his or her legal clearance (notably; after the risk of 
exploiting the youth is down to a more reasonable number, there is of 
course, risk in everything).

That's not unreasonable at all and is very clearly the safest route to 
take. In addition, such a ruling prevents perverse and exploitative 
pedophiles from having legal clearance to hurt a child and protects the 
child if he or she was threatened or persuaded that he or she "wanted it", 
this being a problem we already have and could easily anticipate to worsen 
if we favored the adult's desires over the child's safety.

comments.text:
+Nynke de Haan You can try reporting it, but it's standard practise to 
leave the decision up to the parents for 16-18 year olds, and let the 
alledged victim have a say too.
If you report and the parents don't see a problem when the police enquires, 
no case will be created, and there are no appeal options. 

Generally the law on abusive sex (ontucht) goes:
Sexual relations with someone under 12, always a crime. Max sentence 12 
years in prison. The prosecution has instructions to drop all cases against 
minors (0-15 year old) except in exceptional circumstances. 16-18 year olds 
can be convicted, but will probably receive a slap on the wrist at most 
unless actual sexual abuse is proven.

12-16 years old, cases can be pursued by the parents, but if the other 
partner (the accused) is a minor there are instructions to not create a 
case. If the partner is an adult 18-21 , a case can only become a court 
case if abuse seems likely, meaning almost all such cases get dropped.

16-18 year olds are considered capable of consent to relationships. It's 
extremely difficult to create a case out of that. You would need to make 
sexual abuse in the form of coercion or exploitation (dwang, uitbuiting of 
manipulatie) likely. For example if the girl doesn't speak a word of Dutch, 
is from Russia and works as a prostitute, there would be a court case. But 
if she's happy with the way things are and there's no reason to assume the 
partner is manipulating her, no case will be created.


Laws regarding 'Ontucht' come mainly from article 247 of the Criminal 
Lawbook (wetboek van strafrecht).
Most of the legal instructions are based on the "Memorie van toelichting 
Goedkeuring verdag inzake de bescherming van kinderen tegen seksuele 
uitbuiting en seksueel misbruik"

comments.text:
Odd off-shoot here, but does anyone ever find that fanfic blurs the line of 
consent a lot?

I don't watch porn very often, for some strange reason I've always 
preferred to read it. And, in my experience, the *majority* of sexual 
encounters in fanfic are not obviously consensual in the beginning but 
usually end in the couple riding happily away into the sunset after a love 
confession. 

This does appear to give the impression that 'no' does not actually mean 
'no' or at least, as Hank mentioned, that the absence of the woman saying 
'no' means 'yes'.

I'm not pretending to be all 'holier-than-thou' in this, I personally 
prefer stories where there is some reluctance on the part of the woman. Not 
because they aren't attracted to the male character but because some 
emotional or situational hang-up gets in the way. Logically, I know that 
'no' should mean 'no', but I find a certain level of reluctance hot for 
some reason. As, it seems, do most authors and readers. Why is this?

It's a bit different from video porn, I imagine, because with written porn 
is much more narrative and character-focused, by virtue of it being written 
from someones perspective and within the context of pre-existing complex 
characters. It's also written mostly by women, for women, from the 
perspective of women, which you would think has an effect as well...

I don't know, any thoughts?

As a side note, I never read the more dark 'rape, humiliation and domestic 
abuse' stories (it's kind a sub-genre?), those just make me angry. If I do 
read them, it's more because I start them unwittingly and then desperately 
want the female character to escape, kill the man or even just kill herself 
in the really disturbing ones. 

And to any non-fanfic readers out there, no, not all smutty fanfic is like 
50 Shades of Grey. I promise you, the realm of smutty fanfic on the 
internet is the most diverse reservoir of pornographic material known to 
mankind. With a wide variety of writing quality (some better than anything 
original I've ever read)﻿

comments.text:
Besides the topics discussed in the video, two other major issues that 
hinder our progress are:

1.) Willfully lying to your significant other; voluntarily doing something 
sexual that you really don't want to do in an effort not to want to "hurt 
their feelings" or some shit like that. You're keeping the lines blurred, 
making it difficult to allow others to perceive if you feel like you're 
feeling pressured into doing something.

2.) Lack of Consent =/= Regret, and vice versa.
If you wake up in the morning feeling like you made a mistake and were not 
coerced into making that mistake, then there shouldn't be an issue. This 
issue way too subjective, as the feeling of "being pressured" could be 
either from actual coercion or simply fickleness ("being on the fence", 
maybe just a little convincing, not manipulation), or that feeling could 
even develop as a defense mechanism to justify the regret if there was any 
initial doubt and exchange that occurred prior at all.﻿
